context: Microbial community compositions from water and textile samples were compared using DGGE, and analysed by clustering using Pearson correlation and UPGMA methods. Complex community patterns were observed for basin water and textile samples and were significantly altered compared to inflow groundwater (Fig. 7 ). Water samples from the basins were very similar, whereas textile samples differed from each other and also from all water samples.Total organic carbon (TOC), chemical oxygen demand (COD), and biological oxygen demand (BOD) The system showed overall reductions of 61% for COD, 57–59% for TOC, and 71–73% for BOD. These parameters together with the calculated electron equivalents for the COD values and the summarized average MTBE, benzene, iron(II) and ammonium concentrations are shown (Table 4 ). To facilitate better comparison, the organic carbon content based on the MTBE and benzene concentrations was calculated and individual POC/NPOC values are provided for inflow and outflow groundwaters. The TOC fractions in the inflow were 29.5% and 70.5% for NPOC and POC, respectively. The NPOC showed no significant decrease whereas the POC decreased up to 92%, and equals the calculated sum of MTBE and benzene in mg C/L.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methoxy-2-methylpropane and ammonium are mentioned in relation to the analysis of microbial community compositions and water quality parameters. However, there is no direct interaction or specific relationship discussed between the two compounds. Ammonium concentrations are reported alongside other parameters, but 2-methoxy-2-methylpropane is not linked to ammonium in any functional or chemical context.
